title: Ö1
text:
Österreich 1 (Ö1) is an <a href="Austria">Austria</a>n <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a>: one of the four national channels operated by Austria's <a href="Public%20broadcasting">public broadcaster</a> <a href="ORF%20%28broadcaster%29">ORF</a>. It focuses on <a href="classical%20music">classical music</a> and <a href="opera">opera</a>, <a href="jazz">jazz</a>, <a href="Radio%20documentary">documentaries and features</a>, <a href="News%20broadcasting">news</a>, <a href="Radio%20drama">radio plays</a> and dramas, "<a href="Kabarett">Kabarett</a>", quiz shows, and discussions.
History.
The channel was launched on 1 October 1967 as part of an exercise which saw the ORF's radio output reorganized into three numbered services, the other two being the regional stations grouped as <a href="%C3%962">Ö2</a> and the pop music channel <a href="Hitradio%20%C3%963">Ö3</a>.
Earlier, in 1964, there had been a petition for a national <a href="referendum">referendum</a>, whereby more than 800,000 citizens declared themselves against ideological appointments of key positions within the public broadcasting service by the Austrian <a href="grand%20coalition">grand coalition</a> government of Chancellor <a href="Alfons%20Gorbach">Alfons Gorbach</a> (<a href="%C3%96VP">ÖVP</a>) and Vice-Chancellor <a href="Bruno%20Pittermann">Bruno Pittermann</a> (<a href="SP%C3%96">SPÖ</a>) according to the Austrian "<a href="Proporz">Proporz</a>" system. Two years later, a legal regulation of a nonpartisan broadcasting was passed by the <a href="National%20Council%20%28Austria%29">National Council</a> parliament, entailing a relaunch of the ORF radio stations.
Ö1 was designated to comply with the public educational mandate ("Bildungsauftrag") and to offer a broadly cultural program for an artistically inclined audience. One focus is on news broadcasts like the one-hour "Mittagsjournal" ("Noon Journal") and "Morgenjournal" ("Morning Journal"), launched in the course of the coverage of the 1968 <a href="Prague%20Spring">Prague Spring</a>. Beside established programmes such as "Du holde Kunst", first aired in 1945, Ö1 since the 1970s has also broadcast <a href="Radio%20documentary">radio documentaries</a> ("Hörbilder"), music programmes beyond the strictly classical canon ("Pasticcio", "Spielräume"), and several recurring reports on <a href="everyday%20life">everyday life</a> in a <a href="feuilleton">feuilleton</a> style like "Der Schalldämpfer" by <a href="Axel%20Corti">Axel Corti</a> (discontinued upon his death in 1993). Similar to other classical music radio stations, Ö1 has to bear with the tension between an elitist ""<a href="Geheimrat">Hofrat</a>" widow broadcaster" and a "Classic FM" popularisation, with the station's style and scheduling a matter of ongoing debates.
Operation.
Ö1 broadcasts from Funkhaus Wien on Argentinierstrasse in the <a href="Wieden">Wieden</a> district of <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>. The current <a href="station%20identification">station identification</a> was composed by the jazz musician <a href="Werner%20Pirchner">Werner Pirchner</a> in 1994, the <a href="slogan">slogan</a> "Ö1 gehört gehört"—a pun on "to be heard" in German conforming with "ought to"—was created by the author <a href="Wolf%20Haas">Wolf Haas</a>. The interval signal of Ö1 is a three-note chord, played on a viola. There were two earlier versions of the signal: first one was played by harpsichord and the second one by a synth.
Since 2010 a 75-minute altered block of programming is broadcast every morning on the <a href="Shortwave%20radio">shortwave</a> frequencies of former <a href="Radio%20%C3%96sterreich%20International">Radio Österreich International</a> as Ö1 International. Ö1 <a href="internet%20radio">internet radio</a> can also be listened to live on the ORF website through <a href="streaming%20media">streaming audio</a>, the programmes can also be heard for a week after broadcast at no charge. Several are available as <a href="download">download</a>s and <a href="podcast">podcast</a>s.
Ö1 runs the RadioKulturhaus venue in Funkhaus Wien including the KulturCafé <a href="Viennese%20coffee%20house">coffee house</a>. It also participates in the annual <a href="Donauinselfest">Donauinselfest</a> music festival.
